sp.p: I am no gentleman born, my father was a poor Fletcher in Grubstreet, but I am a gentleman by my place.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What place?

sp.speaker: Bo.
sp.l: A justice's clerk, sir Jeffery wiseacres.

sp.speaker: Je.
sp.p: My man, if it please your majesty, an honest true knave.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Give to sir wiseacres clerk an hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Jef.
sp.l: I thank your grace.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: God confound all your foes at the same rate.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: But if this Wallace, sirrah, be alive now,
You and your hundred pounds shall both be hanged.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Nay I will be hanged ere I part from my money,
Who pays, who pays?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Charge, charge.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: The news brave Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.p: The daring scot fuller of insolence than strength stand forth to bid us battle.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Throw defiance back down their throats, and of our heralds
Northumberland the honour shall be thine, tell 'em
We come to scourge their pride with whips of steel,
Their city hath from justice snatched her sword
To strike their sovereign, who has turned the point
Upon their own breasts, tell 'em this.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I shall. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Where's noble Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I have a message, but 'tis more honourable, sent to you too,
The herald says that Wallace dares ye, his
Spite is all at you, and if your spirit be great
as his, you find him in the rear.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Hang up that wiseacres, and the fool his man.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: My master, not me sir, I have a recognizance of him
To stand betwixt me and the gallows.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: A King's word must be kept, hang 'em both.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: One word more good sir, before I go to this gear,
If a King's word must be kept, why was it not kept, when he gave me the 100. li. wipe out one, I'll wipe out the other.

sp.speaker: King
sp.p: That jest hath saved your lives, let me see you fight today.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Bravely like cocks.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: Now Wallace look to your coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Move on.

div.stage: Enter to them the Scottish army, and are beaten off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We have fleshed them soundly.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: I would not wish to meet with braver spirits.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: Stay, Bruce, what's yonder on the hill?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: They are colours.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why do they mangle thus their armies limbs?
What's that so far off?

sp.speaker: Br.
sp.l: Sure 'tis the rear, where burns the black brand,
Kindles all this fire, I mean the traitor Wallace?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What turned coward?
A dog of so good mouth, and stand at bay?
If in this heat of fight we break their ranks,
Press through, and charge that devil, Bruce thyself.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: To hell if I can chase him.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Charge up strong, hark, brave,
Let now our hands be warriors, not our tongues.

div.stage: Enter the Scottish army, general Grimsby, coming, Mentith.

sp.speaker: A cry within.
sp.l: They fly, they fly.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.l: The English shrink, knit all our nerves
And fasten fortunes offer.

sp.speaker: Gri.
sp.l: Keep steady footing, the day is lost if you stir,
Stir not, but stand the tempest.

sp.speaker: Coming.
sp.l: I cry on.

sp.speaker: General
sp.l: And I.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.p: So do not I, this starting back is but an English earthquake, which to dust, shakes rotten towers, but builds the sound more strong.

sp.speaker: General
sp.l: Let's on, and dare death in the thickest throng.

div.stage: Enter the English army, and encompass them.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Did I not give you warning of this whirlpool
For going too far?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: We are all dead men, yet fight
So long as legs and arms last.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: In how quick time
Have we about you built a wall of brass?
Had he whom here you call your general
A soldier been remarkable of great breeding,
And now to be caught with lime-twigs?

sp.speaker: General.
sp.l: Keep our ground.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: If we must fall, fall bravely.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Wound for wound.

sp.speaker: Alarum.
sp.l: Exeunt King and Bruce pursuing the Scots.

div.stage: Clifford, Percy, Grimsby, and general stay.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.p:
Take breath, I would not have the world robbed
of two such spirits, post to the King, and tell him that the noblest hearts of the whole herd are hunted to the toil,
Ask whether they shall fall, or live for gain.

sp.speaker: Messenger.
sp.l: I shall.
Charge.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: For honour's sake come down, and save thy country.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whose is the day?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: 'Tis Edward's, come rescue
Our general, and the noble Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Who?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our general and stout Grimsby are enclosed
With quicksets made of steel, come fetch them off,
Or all is lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Is the day lost?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Lost, lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Unless the day be quite lost, I'll not stir.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: 'Tis quite lost.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then descend amain, art sure 'tis lost?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Then we'll win it again.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How now?

sp.speaker: Messenger
sp.l: The King proclaims that man a traitor
That saves when he may kill.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Charge them black day,
The lion hunts a lion for his prey.
A fight.

div.stage: Enter Wallace and soldiers, beat off the English, the general, and Grimsby slain.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.l: Too late.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Why then farewell,
I'll make what haste I can to follow thee,
Bruce, Bruce, I am here, 'tis Wallace calls thee,
Dares thee.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Though I ne'er stooped unto a traitor's lure,
I scorn thine, why dost thou single me,
Yet turnst thy weapon downward to the earth?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Let's breathe and talk.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: I'll parley with no traitor but with blows.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Ye shall have blows your guts full,
I am no traitor.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.p: Why 'gainst thy sovereign lifts thou then thy sword?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: You see I lift it not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Tell Edward so thy King.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Longshancks was never sovereign of mine,
Nor shall whilst Bruce lives, Bruce is my sovereign,
Thou art but bastard English, Scotch true born,
Thou'rt made a mastive 'mongst a herd of wolves,
To weary those thou shouldst be shepherd of.
The fury of the battle now declines,
And take my counsel, though I seem thy foe,
Wash both thy hands in blood, and when anon
The English in their tents their deeds do boast,
Lift thou thy bloody hands up, and boast thine,
And with a sharp eye note, but with what scorn,
The English pay thy merit.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: This I'll try.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Darest thou alone meet me in Glasco-moore,
And there I'll tell thee more?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Thou hast no treason towards me?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Here's my hand,
I am clear as innocence, had I meant treason
Here could I work it on thee, I have none.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: In Glasco-moore I'll meet thee, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: The time.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Some two hours hence.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: There I will untie
A knot, at which hangs death or sovereignty.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We have sweat hard today.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: 'Twas a brave hunting. Bolt offers to lay his coat under the King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Sit, some wine
Away in the field all fellows, whose is this?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: It was my coat at arms, but now 'tis yours at legs.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Away, why givest thou me a cushion?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Because of the two, I take you to be the better man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A soldier's coat shall never be so base
To lie beneath my heel, thou'rt in this place
My fellow, and companion, a health to all in England.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: Let it come.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Is not this he that killed Wallace?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.l: No sir, I am only he that said so,
As you sit, so did I lie.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Sirrah, where's your master?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: My master is shot.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How shot, where?

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.l: I'th back.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: O he ran away.

sp.speaker: Bol.
sp.p: No, my lord, but his harness cap was blown off, and he running after it to catch it, was shot between neck and shoulders, and when he stood upright he had two heads.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Two heads how?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Yes truly, his own head and the arrow head, it was twenty to one that I had not been shot before him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: Because my knight's name being wiseacres, and mine bolt, and you know a fool's bolt is soon shot.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.p: He has pinned the fool upon his master's shoulder very handsomely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Sirrah, go seek your master, and bid him take order for burying of the dead.

sp.speaker: Bolt.
sp.p: I shall sir, and whilst he takes order for the burials of the dead, I'll take order for the stomachs of the living.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How fought today our English?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Bravely.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: How the Scots?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The pangs of war are like to childbed throws
Bitter in suffering, but the storm being passed,
The talk, as of 'scaped shipwreck sweet, doth taste,
The death of the Scotch general went to my heart,
He had in him of man as as any,
And for ought I think, his blood was poorly sold
By his own countrymen, rather than sought by us.
Had not the rear where Wallace did command,
Stood and given aim, it had been a day
Bloody and dismal, and whose hard to say,
Sir, you shall give me leave to drink a health
To all the valiant Scots.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clifford, I'll pledge thee, give me my bowl.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Sir, I remembered Wallace in my draught.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: I did not, so this cup were Wallace skull,
I'd drink it full with blood, for it would save
The lives of thousands.

sp.speaker: Clif
sp.l: I for your kingdoms would not pledge it so.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I would, no matter how a traitor falls.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Percy, ten thousand crowns should buy
That traitor's head, if I could have't for money.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I would give
Twice twenty thousand crowns to have his head
On my sword's point cut from him with this arm,
But how i'th field, nobly, hand to hand, not this straw
To a hangman that should bring it me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Let that pass,
Where's Bruce, our noble Earl of Carrick?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: I saw him not today,

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I did, and saw his sword
Like to a reaper's scythe, mow down the Scots.
Here he comes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Brave armoury, a rampant lion within a field all gules,
Where hast been Bruce?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Following the execution which we held
Three English miles in length.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him some wine, art not thirsty?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes for Scottish blood, I never shall have
Enough on't, the King's health.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Let come.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How greedily you Scot drinks his own blood!

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: K.
sp.l: If he should taste your bitterness, 'twere not well.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What's that ye all laughed at?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Nothing but a jest.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Nay, good sir tell me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: An idle jest, more wine for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No more, I have drunk too much,
Wallace and I did parley.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: How in words?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No Percy, I'm no prater, 'twas with swords,
Your laughing jest was not at me?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Sir, no.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Bruce would fain quarrel,

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I ha' done sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Peace, what trumpet's that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: From the enemy sure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Go learn.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: I come from Wallace.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: So sir, what of him?

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: Thus he speaks.
He bids me dare you to a fresh battle, by to morrow's sun,
Army to army, troup to troup, he challenges,
Or to save blood, fifty to fifty, shall the strife decide,
Or one to one.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A herald to the traitor.
Go and thus speak, we bring whips of steel,
To scourge rebellion, not to stand the braves
Of a base daring vassal, bid him ere that sun
Which he calls up be risen, pay it and save
His country and himself from ruin, charge him on his head,
To make his quick submission; if he slow the minutes,
We'll proclaim in thunder his and his country's ruin,
Go be gone, arm.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.l: Arm, arm.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A land that's sick at heart must take sharp pills,
For dangerous physic best cures dangerous ills.

div.head: Actus v.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: As you are a soldier, as you're noble
I charge you and conjure you to unclasp
A book in which I am gravelled.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Perhaps I cannot.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Yes, if you dare you can.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Dare? Clifford dares
Do any thing but wrong and what's not just.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Then tell me sir, what was that bitter scorn,
Which I like poison tasted in my wine?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: I care not if I do, because I love virtue even in
My enemy, the bowl of wine kissing your lip.
Behold, quoth one how eagerly you scot,
Drinks his own blood.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: You Scot drinks his own blood, which scot?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Best wake some oracle.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Who broke the jest upon me?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Pray pardon me. Exit Cli

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: The oracle I'll wake is here, o Wallace,
I never had eyes till now, they were closed up
By braving English, witchcraft drinks his own blood,
England my stepdame take my bitter curse,
Thy own nails tear thy own bowels, o my parent
Dear Scotland, I no more will be a goad,
Pricking thy sides, but if ere I draw a sword,
It shall be double-edged with blood and fire,
To burn and drown this kingdom and this King.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My general
Charged me in privacy to give you these.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Thanks noble Clifford, what did he bid thee say?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Nothing but so. Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A pair of spurs, Bruce ne'er was runaway,
Twelve silver pence, o bitter scorn, with Judas,
I have betrayed my master, my dear country,
And here's the emblem of my treachery,
To hasten to some tree, and desperate die,
Twelve sterling silver pence, sterling, ha sterling,
'Tis a limb of Scotland, spurs for flight,
Clifford, I'll thither, comment I wrong or right.

div.stage: Enter Grimsby, Mentith, coming, English herald, and Rouge-crosse.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Stay noble Grimsby, ere he further pass
One of us certify our general,
Perhaps he'll not admit him to his presence.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: 'Tis like so, stay him here, that pains be mine.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Let Ruge-crosse bring his pleasure.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Come agreed.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You bring from Longshanks some strange message now.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: At lest he sends his gauntlet.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.l: Gauntlet, no the English
Fight not two days together, but like swaggerers,
A fray being made up with a wound or so,
The man whose throat before should have been cut,
is a sworn brother, now we have malled your nation,
They'll fawn on us like spaniels, will they not?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And that's thy errand, is't not?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Commonly, when English see at cuffs they are too weak, they fall to fishing, and then bait the hook with mercy, and the King's pardon, at which who bites has his swallowing spoilt for ever, there's no scot but scorns to hang his hope on your King's promises, be it ne'er so smoothly gilded.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.l: He gilds none sir.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: I warrant he would pawn half his dominions to shake hands with Wallace, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Had he but him in's court, he would outshine
His capering gallants, be would dote on him,
As Jupiter did on Ganymede, and make him
His chief minion.

sp.speaker: Herald.
sp.p: He does already so really dote upon him, 'tis not yet the age of one hour since my master sware to give ten thousand crowns to scot or English, that were so bold to bring him wallace's head.

sp.speaker: Ruge.
sp.l: The English herald.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Ten thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Would make a fair show in our purses Jack.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I could pick out five thousand heads,
That I durst boldly sell him at that rate.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Ten thousand crowns.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I and court windfalls too,
Some English earldom or so, here is none but friends,
Should you betray the conference, I care not,
I would deny it, and I would o'ersway
Your proofs though ne'er so massy.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: It shall not need, believe me worthy Mentith.
What here you look is safe.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.p: Shall we earn this English gold, ten thousand crowns?

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My hand.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: They are ours, he's dead.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: No more, he comes.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I am to him no vassal, he's a tyrant,
So tell him, ere his frown shall bend my knee,
This shall be hanged upon the gallow tree,
For my appearance tell him this, I'll dine
On Christmas day next in his English court,
And in his great hall at Westminster, at's own board,
We'll drink Scotch healths in his standing cups of gold:
His black jacks hand in hand about his court
Shall march with our blue bonnets, we'll eat nothing
But what our swords shall carve, so tell his soldiers,
We'll sit like lords there whilst they rail like slaves,
Go with Scotch threats, pay back your English braves.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: You'll make the English mad. Exit herald.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.l: A brave defiance.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Defiance,
Let's mad them more, they shall not sleep tonight ,
Good Grimsby beat a drum, let bonfires shine
Through all our army, as if our tents were burned,
And we dislodged, but recollect our troops
Into an ordered body, some thing we'll do
To make our chronicles swell with English rue.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: A drum, call a drum. Exit Grimsby.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: O sir John Mentith I have cracked the ice,
To a design, which if it will succeed,
England no more shall strike, nor Scotland bleed.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Come. Let's be partakers, dear sir.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: What will you say, if I win Bruce from the English?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: The happiest day that ever shone on Scotland.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: And crown him King?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: That's the upshot must crown all, I'm to meet him
Before one hour grow old in Glasco-moore.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: How meet him?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: As I am, both come alone, no words to any.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Our lips are sealed.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Will you ride, or go on foot?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: No more, I'll ride.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: We'll pass the wood on foot.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Jack Mentith, I do laugh to think what face,
Longshancks will make, when he shall hear what guests
Will dine with him in's court on Christmas day.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: What face? he'll kill the herald sure.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.p: Oh! some charm for me to be invisible there, and see him.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: For my part, of ten thousand crowns by this hand,
I do wish you there.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: For as many of mine, I swear.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Time may come,
In his exchequer we may share twice that sum.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: Hence, hie you before, keep close in the wood,
Break forth if you spy treason, if not, not.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Good. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Ha, if what thou seemest thou art, step forward, speak,
I have faced more horrid terror.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Whare dost gang?

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: What's that to thee?

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Thouse not lest and lang,
Twa wolves will suck thy blood, by the third night,
I charge thy soul meet mine, thy death is dight.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Thou art a lying spirit.

sp.speaker: Fryer.
sp.l: Bruce been thy bane,
Give on thou gang luke not turn back again,
Wallace beweere, methinks it thee should irk,
Mare need hast thou to serve God in the kirk.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Stay, if thou hast a voice thou'rt blood and bone,
As I am, let me feel thee, else I'll think thee
A sorcerous imaginary sound:
Stand me, thou'rt some English damned witch,
That from a reverend friar has stolen his shape
To abuse me — stay — art gone? no hag I will not.
It spoke sure, told me Bruce shouldExit ghost beckoning him to follow.
Be my bane, — cannot — shall not,
Heaven knows such things only.
That eye hath shot me throw, wounds me to death,
I know that face too well, but 'tis so ghastly,
I'll rather with my nails here dig my grave,
Then once more behold thee. Exit ghost.
Part from me vexed spirit, my blood turns to water,
I beseech thee affright me not — it's gone.

sp.speaker: Peg.
sp.l: Alas Scotland to wham salt thou complain,
Alas, fra mourning wha sall thee refrain?
I thee beseek and for him died on tree,
Come not near Bruyce, yet Bruyce sall not hurt thee,
alas, alas, no man can stand 'gainst fate.
The damp dew fra the heaven does 'gin to favu,
I to my rest mim gange ere the cock crawe.

sp.speaker: Wall.
sp.l: It was my wife, what horror meet I here?
No armour in the world can hold out fear.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: We stay for your direction.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Whom did you meet?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Nobody .

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: Saw ye nothing?

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Not any thing.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: 'Twas my brains weakness then,
I have seen strange sights, that anon I'll tell;
If Grimsby we meet never more, farewell. Exit.

sp.speaker: Grim.
sp.l: Ha, I am struck dumb, o man's slippery fate!
Mischiefs that follow us at our backs we shun,
And are struck down with those we dream not on.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have beside with Wallace sheriff of life,
Held private conference, who in longshancks name,
Who swears to me we shall have good preferment,
Beside the promised gold. Enter Wallace.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: Peace, Wallace comes.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Is the Bruyce come?

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: It is not yet his hour.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Who came along with you?

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: My footboy only, who is tying up my horse.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Him must I kill.
I'll look if Bruce be in sight yet —Exit.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Do.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: You're sad.

sp.speaker: Wa.
sp.l: My mind is shaken but the storm is o'er,
What cry is that?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Be armed, Bruce with a force comes to betray thee,
From some villain's hand thy footboy is murdered.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Murdered? Bruce shall repent this deed.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: So shalt thou, away with him.

div.stage: Enter soldiers, knock him down, hurry him away in a sound. Exeunt.
Enter Bruce muffled with a soldier.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Help to disguise me soldier, in exchange
Take these for thine, and here's some gold to boot.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: If I be not hanged, my lord, in all my bravery,
I care not.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Phew, I warrant thee,
Seal up thy lips and eyes, thou neither seest
Nor canst tell where I am.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Not I my lord.
O my poor wronged country, pardon me heaven,
And with a feather plucked from mercy's wing,
Brush off the purple spots, that else would grow,
Like freckles on my soul.

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: My lord, here comes company.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here quick mine own again, and get thee gone.

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Sirrah soldier, sawest thou the Earl of Huntington?

sp.speaker: Soldier
sp.l: Huntington?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The lord Bruce, I mean.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Who calls for Bruce?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Muffled up, and alone, I'll to the King. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Do, sirrah be gone.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Whither's Percy gone? he asked for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: There's great enquiry for you.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: The King has a fresh command for Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: For me? he may command his subjects.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: True, and Huntington is one.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Is none.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: No subject?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: None that dare oppose your King, o my impostumed spleen,
Will fly into their faces, what command
Has England now?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Fresh powers are to be levied,
Which Bruce of Huntington must lead.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: 'Gainst whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: 'Gainst proud Wallace, 'gainst the Scots.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: I will not, I'm not his butcher,
'Gainst the Scots I will not fight.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: How, will not?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: No, will not Clifford.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Peace.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: My lord, I dare not,
In this last battle I received some wounds
That yet bleed inward, I will no more banquet strangers
With my native blood.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Bruce speaks not like a subject.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: English Edward commands not like a King,
Thrice honoured Clifford, I'll trust you with my bosom.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: No, you shall not.
My virgin honour is so chaste, it shall not
Keep company with a disquiet bosom,
Nor talk with discontents.

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: It shall not, I will but,
Spare me, the air hath ears no more,
You sent to me, I will but tell bold Clifford
Not a word,
My thoughts owe as much honour as their lord.
Within traitor, traitor. Enter Mentith.

div.stage: Enter King, North, Herefor, and followers.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: A mutiny, what noise is't?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.l: Mentith, a knight of Scotland.

sp.speaker: Cliff.
sp.l: Keep him off.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What comest thou for?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Comyn my countryman and I have brought
A jewel to your highness, which if 'twere right
As 'tis known counterfeit, 'twere worth a kingdom,
Wearied with war, and pitying the deep wounds
Which fainting Scotland bears upon her breast,
And knowing that the only sword which gashes
Her tender sides, is gripped in Wallace hands,
I in my love to peace, and to the safety
Of two great nations, am the man that laid
Snares to entrap this monster, that devours
So many thousand lives, the rebel's ta'en.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Where is he?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: I have brought him to your English camp,
Force would not do't, but policy, we struck the stag
To the ground, and thought him dead, but heaven put back
The blow of purpose, he's now come to life,
From an astonishment when we thought him dead,
To th'end the world may see the public shame
Of an archtraitor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Mentith hath won fame,
And honour by this act, fetch in this devil. Exit ment.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Thou wilt have England's thanks, but Scotland's curse,
Thou never haste done better, never worse,
Damned Judas to thy countryman and friend.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Where am I?

sp.speaker: Bru.
sp.l: Here with Bruce.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Bruce my sovereign?
My blood is sold, this is not Glasco-moore,
Some villain hath betrayed me.

sp.speaker: Cli.
sp.l: Speak to your countrymen, Comyn and Mentith.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Comyn and Mentith?
Something it was that made the modest night
Look angry on the world, I this was it,
And this was it that cleft my father's grave,
And raised him from his monumental bed of earth
To give me gentle warning, this was it,
That made my star, when all the rest looked pale,
Blush like a fiery meteor, can heaven wink at this?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: It can, it doth, and at far greater mischiefs.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not of thy acting?

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Yes of mine.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Not here.

sp.speaker: Ment.
sp.l: Here or in hell.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Why then go act them there,
Boast of them there, in that black kingdom tell
That by a true subject a base rebel fell.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What's that?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Your Scotch jeweller is slain,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: By whom?

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: By Wallace.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Hear me speak King Edward.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Good my liege hear him,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Clif. I have vowed,
Neither to hear nor see him, drag him hence,
Mine eye shall nor be so compassionate
To view him, lest I pity him: hang, draw, and quarter him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: First hear me speak,

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Drag him hence, and let that heart, those limbs,
Which were the motives to rebellious war
Be torn asunder, cast upon that ground,
Which he with unkind steel so oft did wound,
Away with him.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: Farewell, to all the world,
I ha' met death too often to fear him now,
Only it grieves me that I have not freed
Scotland my native soil from tyranny,
Bruce, thou hast a kingdom, lose it not.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Stop his throat.

sp.speaker: Wal.
sp.l: I go to one too,
And on my grave, when death hath there down laid me,
Be this my epitaph, mine own betrays me —Exit.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Let him have noble trial.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: He shall have the trial of an archtraitor,
Percy and Clifford take hence Bruce.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Me hence?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: You hence sir, from this hour I swear,
Never to see thee Earl of Huntingdon,
Hark Clifford, and Northumberland, away

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: What is King Edward's meaning?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Your head shall feel our meaning, see it dispatched.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: You may. Exeunt Bruce, North and Clifford.

sp.speaker: Com.
sp.l: My honoured lord, although untimely death,
Hath taken hence one engine of that work,
that brought that rebel Wallace to his end.
Seeing our country's peace, and England's good,
Is by his death made perfect and complete,
I doubt not but the promised reward
Of full ten thousand crowns shall now remain,
To the survivor.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Coming, I perceive
It was reward, not love that acted it,
But you shall have your due, of that anon. A flourish.
I told thee Bruce, that thou upon thy head,
Shouldst feel our meaning, and that all the world,
May know we value honour above conquest,
Having a power able to turn all Scotland
Into a chaos, here twixt both our armies,
Give us thy oath of fealty, and wear
Both crown and title of thine ancestors.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: England is full of honour, Bruce doth bend
To thy command. They crown him.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Give him his oath of fealty,
With him those lords which are his countrymen.

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: Stand back, a serpent shall not with his breath
Infect our kingly ears, die slave, for he
That would betray his friend shall ne'er serve me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: What hath Bruce done?

sp.speaker: Bruce.
sp.l: A sacrifice of honour and revenge, no traitors hand
Shall help to lift a crown up to my head,
Thou didst betray, then die unpitied.

sp.speaker: Clif.
sp.l: Brave Bruce, I'll love thee for this honoured act,
Thou hast performed a noble piece of justice:
Now shall the ghost of Wallace sleep in peace,
And perfect love shall twixt these lands increase.
He hath his full reward for his foul treason,
Drag hence the slave, and make him food for crows.
The lamp that gave rebellion light, hath spent
The oil that fed it, all our spears are turned
To palms and olive branches, all our stars
Are now made whole, peace is the balm of wars.

A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
